website_summaries.verdict: A brand synonymous with amazing coffee making for more than a century, so no surprise that this single-cup dripper is both fashionable and cost-effective.
pros: Made from porcelain, which retains heat better and is more durable
Costs around the same – or less – than plastic drippers
Users love the smooth, full flavor
Dishwasher safe, so cleanup is easy
cons: May be a bit too small if coffee cup is more than 4” wide

customer_reviews.title: Hole is too big.
customer_reviews.text: This is too big for s #2. More like a #4. Drains way too quickly. I've used this method most of my adult life. I can't believe this is even made by Melitta. I used toothpicks, cut to size and laid loosely along the bottom, to slow the drainage. Very pretty and easy to clean, so I'm keeping it.
customer_reviews.author: Kathryn Page

customer_reviews.title: It's poorly made although heavy and sturdy, the base is not flat (see picture)
customer_reviews.text: It's poorly made although heavy and sturdy, the base is not flat (see picture), does not sit stably on a cup.

customer_reviews.title: Porcelain vs Plastic
customer_reviews.text: This lets water through a little faster than my plastic cones, giving the coffee a little less bite but also meaning it's not quite as strong. Downside is that it's big and heavy and makes me nervous to perch it on top of a mug. I'll knock it off and break it one of these days, I'm certain. Find myself reaching for the plastic cone most of the time.
customer_reviews.author: Bruce

customer_reviews.title: back to basics
customer_reviews.text: arrived in good time and in perfect condition...what more can i say about a coffee brewer? i use two tablespoons of fine grind coffee and about 1 1/2 cups of boiling water per generous cup, because the coffee and filter suck up a lot of water. i switched back to this method of brewing because my kcup machine took up too much counter space. in fact, i still have kcups left, so i just cut them open and pour them into the filter. and no fuss and bother cleaning a machine!
customer_reviews.author: harobed

customer_reviews.title: It made an absolutely perfect 20 oz tumbler of coffee
customer_reviews.text: I received my ceramic coffee cone tonight. I immediately put it to use making a 20oz Stainless double wall Yeti Tumbler of hot coffee using the number four Melitta filter. Of course I used more coffee than I would have for a standard cup. It made an absolutely perfect 20 oz tumbler of coffee. I had no problems with it draining too quickly probably because I had a lot of grounds in the filter. I did preheat both the tumbler and the ceramic cone with warm tap water prior to using. This thing is great I'm very pleased I love my coffee!
customer_reviews.author: riorust

customer_reviews.title: I decided to try it and am completely satisfied with it
customer_reviews.text: I was thinking about buying a Keurig machine for my single serve cups of coffee. Then, I read about the Melitta pour-over coffee brewer in the Consumer Reports December Gift Guide. I decided to try it and am completely satisfied with it! It brews a quick, delicious cup of coffee. It's a very affordable brewing system and doesn't create the waste that the coffee-cup machines generate. I upgraded and got the porcelain, which I really like. There are cheaper, plastic versions, but I'm happy with the nicer porcelain.
customer_reviews.author: reading hound

customer_reviews.title: Improved over the years
customer_reviews.text: We had a very old one of these that recently broke. It did such a good job that I searched for a replacement. The "official" Melitta one in porcelain is hard to find but Amazon came through. It is slightly smaller, but works faster and brews better so it's an overall win.
customer_reviews.author: Thomas Almy

customer_reviews.title: It's big
customer_reviews.text: Although this dripper is about the same height as the Hario V60 02, it's a half-inch wider in diameter at the top and weighs just over one pound, which is 4 ounces heavier than the Hario. It will completely swallow a Melitta No.2 filter with room to spare. The one I received is unglazed around the top of the rim, which I didn't like. It does have the small, single hole at the bottom, which is what I was looking for to replace an old Melitta plastic cone. Prefer the Hario for slower "pour over" brews with a gooseneck kettle, but I can see the utility of this Melitta as well.
customer_reviews.author: NJren

customer_reviews.title: Forget this - This was a downgrade from the Melitta's plastic cone
customer_reviews.text: I got this hoping to upgrade from the Melitta plastic cone, but this porcelain one actually works *less* well. My main complaints: - Drain hole is too big. Coffee is weak unless I put in 2-3x the recommended amount of coffee per cup, which gets very expensive very quickly. - There is no "window" on the bottom/foot of the cone where it sits over the mug. So if I'm using this over a mug, I cannot see when my mug is full. TL;DR - my hunt for an upgraded pour over cone continues. Save yourself the time & money and look elsewhere!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: but that is no problem for me - the bottom ring fits nicely into the inside rim of all of my coffee ...
customer_reviews.text: Part of my five stars I'm sure is related to the 100% improvement over what I had been using - but in my opinion, this is the perfectly designed pour over tool. The one i had been using did not have the internal ribs, which is the main reason this one works so well. It is quite a bit larger than I thought it would be, but that is no problem for me - the bottom ring fits nicely into the inside rim of all of my coffee mugs, so it feels very secure on top of my mug when i do my pour over (use it at least once/day). It is extremely well made, love the basic white color.
customer_reviews.author: Upstate NY

customer_reviews.title: Nice, but a bit different.
customer_reviews.text: Fits the filters better because it's taller and is easier to manage because of the handle. Flows through a little faster than the plastic version, probably due to the larger hole, Which is still smaller than other brands. Why they made it larger, I don't know, but I found that throwing a tissue under the filter slows it down a little more so it brews better. Shouldn't have to do that though.

customer_reviews.author: MoeMoe

customer_reviews.title: Poor quality. Exceedingly fragile.
customer_reviews.text: This is the THIRD time I've purchased this exact pourover. First time I accidentally broke it in the sink. Second time, it chipped on day two. Sent it back. Third time, it arrived chipped (didn't notice until later) and got chipped on day two. I'm done. I love that Melitta offers a single small hole. But I'll have my eyes peeled in hopes I find something similar and better quality.
customer_reviews.author: M. Rosich

customer_reviews.title: Arrived chipped and larger than #2 filter
customer_reviews.text: I like making pour over coffee and I'm glad I upgraded from plastic, but this seems larger than it needs to be for #2 filters. Also, it arrived chipped on the top edge, but as it's cosmetic, I'm keeping it. Otherwise, I'm very happy with it in terms of drip speed and coffee quality.
customer_reviews.author: Bryan S

customer_reviews.title: Slow drip for rich flavor.
customer_reviews.text: Drip hole is just right to allow for efficient use of coffee. Large holes in other brands, wasted the coffee and made it too weak. One less electric appliance to deal with. Well balanced and easy to clean.
customer_reviews.author: Susie 59

customer_reviews.title: No return policy!
customer_reviews.text: Ready to return to find no return policy. I now use a plastic, light weight cone and will continue to do so. This is heavy and slides all over the place. Very frustrating that they do not back their product and allow returns. Paper filters I but routinely and they are fine. Rosemary
customer_reviews.author: Rosemary Reilly

customer_reviews.title: Works great for one or two cups of coffee.
customer_reviews.text: Works great for one or two cups of coffee. I loved the plastic mellitta brewer for one cup, but thought porcelain would be better than plastic. It takes a number 4 filter, but still fits nicely over most coffeee cups. Just bought the mellita cone and pitcher combo and that cone, though bigger does not fit on my cup since that cone actually has a smaller diameter base. Therefore, this cone is nicer since it is bigger in diameter and fits on the cup.
customer_reviews.author: serendipity

customer_reviews.title: This is an awesome product and brews a great cup of coffee
customer_reviews.text: This is an awesome product and brews a great cup of coffee! I bought this after a nightmare of purchasing, trying single brew coffee makers that left me unsatisfied! It is somewhat old fashion, but there is nothing to fail in a manual brew. I do miss the convenience of push a button and walk away, but I am used to it now and love the consistently of a Great Melita brewed cup of coffee. And, you get to use your own coffee!!!
customer_reviews.author: Tony A.

customer_reviews.title: The single hole in the bottom makes a difference
customer_reviews.text: All the pour-overs that I have tried have had too many holes in the bottom. This single hole slow flow is what I've been looking for to make a richer brew.
customer_reviews.author: Linda at the Shore

customer_reviews.title: Great
customer_reviews.text: These work great. They're heavy, so your coffee making service will be a little top-heavy (don't bump it). But they look good and they let water flow just as well as a plastic cone. I've tried some porcelain holders from other brands and had problems with water flow and backing up. These are the ones I reccomend.
customer_reviews.author: E. Hons

customer_reviews.title: ... coffee in a French Press and this is the perfect item to filter the oily particulates out of the ...
customer_reviews.text: I make my coffee in a French Press and this is the perfect item to filter the oily particulates out of the coffee before I drink it. The coffee tastes much cleaner and smoother after it has passed thru the filter, and it drains thru quickly with no coffee grounds in the filter.
customer_reviews.author: AB Davidson

customer_reviews.title: Sturdy and cost effective
customer_reviews.text: My husband purchased this for making coffee after our Keurig broke. He uses it several times a day, everyday. Very sturdy: it fell off the kitchen counter on to a linoleum floor, not only didn't it break, there's not even a chip. We also take it camping. Saving $$ by not buying K cups.
customer_reviews.author: Blue Eyed Moose
